conclusion: The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
If the light source moves forward, it will be closer to the objects but still above them.
When the light source moves forward, the shadows will move closer to the objects.
The shadows will be shorter and more compact compared to their current positions.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will become smaller.
The angle between the light source and the objects becomes shallower, resulting in shorter and narrower shadows.
If the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move closer to the objects and become smaller in size.
The light source's proximity to the objects reduces the distance from the light source to the points where the shadows are cast, making the shadows shorter and more compact.
